bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, April 15, 1948

div1.p: Hench has received the Carter material sent by Redd. He is disappointed to see no Reed or Lazear correspondence. Hench inquires if it would be possible for Redd to also send the Carter photographs, as he especially wants to find a photograph of Carter in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to H. Carter Redd, April 15, 1948
div1.opener:
April 15, 1948
Mr. H. Carter Redd
1104 Travelers Building
Richmond, Virginia
My dear Mr. Redd:
div1.p:
I have just returned from a considerable vacation in Florida and
Cuba. The trunk has just arrived and I am delighted to have it. The night
it arrived, I spent the whole evening making a preliminary re-arrangement.
The material had gotten pretty confused and mixed up as the trunk was bumped
around in passage but everything was safe. I have made various piles - one of
reprints written by Doctor Carter, one of reprints or papers written by others,
one of his notebooks and one large pile of his letters and a final large pile
of miscellaneous items.

Of course, I have hardly begun to examine the material but I did
skim through the letters hastily and found none from or to Walter Reed or
Lazear. I was rather disappointed in this. I understood that either you
or his son had come across some letters from or to Reed.

May I assume that there is no hurry about my returning this mass
of material? It is in my home, under constant supervision and will not be
lost. I am so busy that I can only give certain evening hours or hours on
Sunday to the material. It may take weeks for me to go over the material
studiously and with appropriate care, making notes of this and that. When
I return it to you, I can assure you it will be arranged in an orderly manner.
I am going to re-arrange the letters in separate piles so that the correspon-
dence between Doctor Carter and a certain individual is in one place. At the
moment it is pretty much mixed up.

You mentioned in your letter of April 3, “a lot of photographs”.
I wondered if they are unframed if it would be possible for you to send them
to me. There might be therein some rare photograph of Doctor Carter in Cuba
perhaps even with Reed or Lazear. In the material you sent, there are a few
small snapshots, but apparently not taken in Cuba. I would certainly like to
find a photograph of Doctor Carter in Cuba. Of especial interest were the
very few letters from Doctor Carter to his wife and son written from Cuba.
There aren't many and I was disappointed in this. Most of the correspondence
begins some years after 1900. Do you have any idea where there might be some
of his correspondence between 1888 and 1902?

I am sending a carbon copy of this letter to his son, Dr. Henry R. Carter,
Jr. I do appreciate very greatly the courtesy of both of you in letting me go
over the material.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
